profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:34

did.abstract: Writings and other papers by and about the American lyricist E.Y. ("Yip") Harburg

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.
Some of the materials may be stored at the Library's off-campus shelving facility, so researchers should allow at least two business days to have the appropriate boxes paged.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The E.Y. Harburg Collection was established at Yale University by E. Y. Harburg in 1968.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The E.Y. Harburg Collection is the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 83, The E.Y. Harburg Collection in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 2 series as follows: I. Writings. II. Harburgiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The E. Y. Harburg Collection documents Harburg's life and career as a lyricist for musicals, films, and popular songs chiefly through his writings. The Collection also contains correspondence, publicity, reviews, and memorabilia.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edgar Yipsel ("Yip") Harburg was born Irwin Hochberg on April 8, 1896, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. (Some sources give the year of his birth as 1898.) He showed his flair for light verse at an early age, but after graduating from the City College of New York in 1917, he pursued a career in business, while continuing to write in his spare time. After a period of prosperity, his electrical supply company failed in the late 1920s, and he decided to change careers.

Harburg quickly achieved great success as a lyricist. Over the years, he collaborated with many composers, including Jay Gorney, Vernon Duke, Harold Arlen, Jerome Kern, Burton Lane, Sammy Fain, and Jule Styne. Harburg wrote the lyrics for shows such as Finian's Rainbow and films such as The Wizard of Oz. His long list of hit songs includes "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?," "April in Paris," "It's Only a Paper Moon," "Over the Rainbow," and "How are Things in Glocca Morra?"

Harburg's Hollywood career came to a halt in the early 1950s when he was blacklisted. A staunch advocate of a variety of left-leaning causes, Harburg was never a member of the Communist Party. The blacklist did not prevent him from working on Broadway, but his musicals after Finian's Rainbow did not match the success of his earlier works.
Yip Harburg died on March 5, 1981 in Brentwood, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Harburg's writings for the American musical theatre and film, his light verse, songs written for political benefits, and various speeches, articles and testimonials.

The musical productions are arranged in chronological order, and all lyrics, libretti, scores, and notes pertaining to a particular musical, whether authored by Harburg or not, are filed together. Songs used in a musical are arranged, when possible, in their order of appearance in the Broadway production (or motion picture). In cases where a musical took several years to develop and underwent several revisions--as did The Happiest Girl in the World and Darling of the Day, for example--the scripts and notes are arranged chronologically. The songs, however, are arranged in their order of appearance in the Broadway production, and any earlier versions of a song are filed with the final version.
Unpublished individual songs, light verse, songs written for political benefits, and various speeches, articles, and testimonials are all arranged chronologically by category.

odd.head: General
odd.p: When E. Y. Harburg gave his papers to Yale, he labeled the correspondence, publicity, reviews, and memorabilia "Harburgiana." The catch-all term proves, indeed, to be a convenient label for all secondary materials in the collection.
The substantial amount of correspondence concerning specific musical productions has been listed first, organized chronologically by production, and chronologically within each production.

General correspondence is listed next and arranged in alphabetical order by correspondent. Harburg kept copies of many of his own letters. These are preceded by "to" in the list. (Most of the original carbon copies were in poor condition and, therefore, have been photocopied.)

Correspondence regarding Rhymes for the Irreverent, professional affiliations, political and philanthropic activities, and miscellaneous institutional contacts is all arranged chronologically by category.

Harburg's four large scrapbooks have been preserved separately from the 27 boxes of papers. Due to the poor condition of the originals, photocopies have been preserved in Folders 198-201. In a few cases where the items were of special interest, the originals have been preserved separately in Folder 202, and photocopies mark their places in the scrapbooks.

Newspaper clippings, publicity, programs, and articles referring to particular musicals are listed under the show titles in chronological order. General writings about Harburg also are listed chronologically.

Items labeled "Memorabilia" are articles, programs, and invitations that Harburg kept out of professional or personal interest. Except for an occasional reference to him in an article, these materials are not directly related to his work and activities.
